key_points: Bob Costas has covered sports events for over 40 years and cherishes the moment Muhammad Ali lit the Olympic cauldron in 1996.
This moment occurred during a surprise appearance by Ali at the 1996 Olympics in Atlanta, Georgia.
Ali, who died in 2016, was suffering from Parkinson's disease for over 30 years at the time he lit the cauldron.
Dick Ebersol, the head of NBC Sports, kept Costas and cohost Dick Enberg unaware of Ali's participation to ensure their spontaneous reaction.
Ali's appearance caused an audible gasp in the stadium, followed by thunderous applause, reflecting both excitement and poignancy.
Costas views this moment as one of reconciliation for Ali, acknowledging his polarizing past and the respect he garnered.
For Costas, the range of emotions experienced during Ali's appearance was unparalleled in his career covering the Olympics.
He considered Ali a blend of grace and wit, capable of profoundly moving an audience.
Costas's new HBO show Back on the Record premiered Friday.
Muhammad Ali is remembered by Costas as a 'beautiful figure in a brutal sport'.
